title: Project Success & Value
description: Define what project success really means beyond on-time and on-budget delivery.
objectives: Distinguish between traditional success metrics and value-driven success
Understand stakeholder satisfaction as a success factor
Apply the concept of benefits realization
Recognize that project completion is not the same as project success

screens.headline: The Restaurant That 'Succeeded' But Failed

dialogue.text: Alex, our downtown location opened on time, on budget, with everything we planned. By traditional measures, it was a 'successful project.' But it closed after 8 months because customers didn't come. Was it really successful?

screens.learningHook: On-time and on-budget isn't enough. True project success means delivering VALUE—outcomes that matter to stakeholders and the business.

screens.title: Evaluating Project Success
screens.instructions: Analyze three projects and determine if they were TRULY successful—not just by traditional metrics.

results.outcome: Only 2 dishes sell well. Customers returned 8 dishes saying 'not what we expected.' Chef satisfaction: Low.
Staff love it, checkout 40% faster, customer satisfaction up 15%, errors reduced 80%.
10 corporate clients signed. Revenue increased 25%. Team morale high. Carlos calls it 'the best initiative we've done.'

options.text: Yes—on time, under budget, full scope
No—customers rejected most dishes, didn't deliver value
Partial success—met constraints but outcomes mixed

feedback.correct: Correct! Despite meeting time/budget/scope, the project failed to deliver VALUE. Customers rejected the dishes. Traditional metrics passed; value delivery failed.
feedback.incorrect: Meeting time/budget/scope isn't enough. The project OUTCOME matters. Customers rejected 10 of 12 dishes—that's not success.

options.text: No—late and over budget, constraints failed
Yes—delivered tremendous value despite minor constraint misses
No—any constraint miss means failure

feedback.correct: Correct! Despite being 2 weeks late and $5K over, the project delivered massive value: faster checkout, happier customers, fewer errors. Value outweighs minor constraint misses.
feedback.incorrect: Two weeks late and $5K over budget are minor issues compared to 40% faster checkout and 15% customer satisfaction increase. VALUE matters most.

options.text: Yes—met constraints AND delivered business value
No—meeting constraints is just doing your job
Unknown—need more time to evaluate

feedback.correct: Correct! This is the ideal: met constraints (time, budget, scope) AND delivered value (revenue up 25%, happy stakeholders). True success!
feedback.incorrect: Project 3 achieved both: constraint adherence AND value delivery. That's the gold standard of project success.

questions.question: Rank these success factors from MOST to LEAST important for the new restaurant expansion:

options.text: Opens on the exact planned date
Customers love it and keep returning
Stays exactly within budget
Achieves target revenue within 6 months

traditional.limitation: You can 'succeed' on all three and still fail to deliver value

modern.shift: PMBOK 7th Ed emphasizes VALUE DELIVERY over constraint adherence

content.insight: True success requires ALL FOUR dimensions, not just efficiency.

content.definition: Benefits realization is ensuring the project delivers the INTENDED OUTCOMES after completion.
content.pmResponsibility: PMs are increasingly responsible for benefits realization, not just delivery.
content.example: The new restaurant isn't successful when it OPENS—it's successful when it THRIVES.

keyStakeholders.satisfaction: Product meets needs, easy to use

content.insight: A project that makes stakeholders unhappy is NOT successful—even if constraints are met.

framework.shortTerm: Did we deliver on time, budget, scope?

questions: Would stakeholders fund this project again?
Is the deliverable being used as intended?
Did we achieve the business case objectives?
Would the team work together again?
content.insight: Success is measured over TIME, not just at project closure.

screens.title: Defining Success for the Expansion
screens.context: Alex is planning success criteria for the new restaurant expansion. Carlos asks: 'How will we know if this project is truly successful?'

questions.question: Which success criteria should Alex include? Select ALL that represent true success.

options.text: Open within 6 months
Stay within $850K budget
Achieve 85% customer satisfaction within 3 months of opening
Reach profitability within 12 months
Team members want to work on future projects together
Complete all paperwork and close the project file

questions.question: When should Alex measure whether the expansion was TRULY successful?

options.text: At the grand opening
When all invoices are paid
6-12 months after opening (when benefits can be measured)
When Alex moves to the next project

screens.title: Key Takeaways
screens.summary: Project success goes beyond on-time and on-budget. True success means delivering value to stakeholders and the business.
takeaways: Traditional metrics (time, budget, scope) are necessary but NOT sufficient
Four dimensions: Efficiency, Effectiveness, Stakeholder Satisfaction, Business Value
Benefits realization: Ensure intended outcomes are achieved AFTER project closes
Stakeholder satisfaction matters—unhappy stakeholders = unsuccessful project
Measure success over TIME, not just at closure
Ask: Would stakeholders fund this again? Is the deliverable thriving?

characterClosing.text: Our downtown location taught me: 'on time and on budget' isn't success if customers don't come. For this expansion, we'll measure real success—satisfied customers, profitable location, happy team.
